WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 457 May 1981 INDUSTRIAL STRATEGY FOR LATE STARTERS: THE EXPERIENCE OF KENYA, TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA Based on the existing literature and the circumscribed data base, this paper assesses the extent and nature of industrialization in three African countries. After a promising start, the drive to industrialize is now faltering. The record is influenced much more by the colonial legacy and the macro-economic situation of each country than by industrial policy. It is clear that future industrial advance will depend heavily on the pace of rural development. Catering to world markets is not likely to provide a major stimulus for the industrial sector of many African economies in the near-term future.  INDUSTRIAL STRATEGY FOR LATE STARTERS: THE EXPERIENCE OF KENYA, TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA 1. Countries in Sub-Sahara Africa were among the last of the colonies to achieve independence. Their attempts to industrialize have only just begun. In fact, most of these economies even today are dominated by agri- cultural or mineral production. TIey are the late starters and their in- dustrial strategies are influenced by this fact. On the one hand, these late starters can benefit from the world's accumulated technology and ex- perience regarding industrial organization; on the other hand, the estab- lished market positions of earlier industrializers poses special problems for the newcomers. Three of these late starters--Kenya, Tanzania and Zambia-- made a promising beginning during the second half of the 1960s. These economies are similar in several respects, but they have pursued strategies which diverge in crucial areas. The aim of this paper is threefold: - to summarize the record of industrial development of these countries during the last decade and a half; - to explain this record in terms of (i) historical factors, (ii) macro-economic conditions, and (iii) impact of industrial strategies; - to examine some of the issues facing these countries as they design future industrial policies. 2. The title of this paper is somewhat ambiguous and a word of expla- nation may help avoid misleading conclusions. We talk about the industrial strategy for late starters as a group and in fact, there are some aspects of this paper which are relevant in this context. But late starters is a large category consisting of countries in Africa, Asia and elsewhere. There
 -2- are many differences among late starters which have a bearing on strategy choices. Kenya, Tanzania and Zambia are by no means representative of the late-starter group. A. Initial Conditions 3. In the mid-sixties, all three economies had rather small populations (Table 1) compared to many Third World countries; but they were not atypical, in the context of Sub-Sahara Africa 1/. Zambia's per capita income was much higher, but its population was much lower than that of Kenya or Tanzania. Given the limited market for manufactured goods in these economies, one would not expect the manufacturing sector to be large in relation to GDP; in fact, it was even smaller than expected. Regression results for 53 countries (linking value-added in manufacturing with GNP per capita and population) suggest that all three countries had an 'underdeveloped' industrial sector in the early 1960s (Chenery 1961). The degree of underdevelopment was less in Kenya than in the other two countries 2/. 4. We can only speculate as to why the industrial sector in all three cases was 'underdeveloped' at the end of the colonial period. The reasons for Kenya's favoured position are somewhat clearer. Tanganyika came under British control only after World War I having been a German colony for more than three decades up to that time. The number of British settlers in Tanganyika was much smaller than in Kenya 3/. Imports constituted half the total supply of manufactures in Kenya, but the proportion was higher in the other two cases (Table 1). A third of Kenyan manufactures were exported; the corresponding share was somewhat lower in Tanzania and insignificant in Zambia. The bulk of production con- sisted of consumer goods in all three cases. The private sector was dominant, and large enterprises located in the capital city or the copperbelt (Zambia) played a very large role. B. Evolution of Industrial Strategies 7. In our view industrial strategy must define positions on the following issues: (a) How much exphasis should be placed on (i) import substitution; (ii) exports to world markets; and (iii) exports to markets adhering to preferential trade arrangements. (b) To what extent should production cater to 'basic needs' of the majority of the population, taking account of their life- style and purchasing power as against responding to the effective demand of the modernized minority.
 -6- (c) How much emphasis should be placed on the development of those key lines of production (e.g. steel, machinery, etc.) which are believed to be essential for self-reliance and also a rich source of external economies. (d) What emphasis should be placed on equality in spatial distri- bution of firms and on promoting enterprises of small size. (e) What should be the role of (i) the public or parastatal sector; (ii) the private sector; and (iii) foreign capital in invest- ment and production. (f) To what extent should use be made of administrative controls and licensing as against policies using price instrumerts (e.g. taxes, tariffs, etc.) 8. Issues (a) through (d) are concerned with ends, i.e., rate and pattern of industrialization while (e) and (f) focus on means, i.e., the manner in which aims should be pursued. Policies bearing on infrastructure, financial intermediation, training and entrepreneurship are also important for industrial development, particularly in the category of late starters, but in this paper we do not discuss them. Technology policy is also not treated explicitly, but item (d) on the size structure of firms touches on this aspect. 9. The broad contours of industrial strategy in the wake of independence were remarkably similar in the three economies. The First Development Plan of Kenya (1966-70), the Zambian White Paper on Industrial Policy issued in 1964 and Tanzania's First Plan (1964-69) shared a common view of how to go about industrializing. All three countries opted for the capitalistic road. All three recognized the dearth of indigenous entrepreneurship as the critical impediment and put heavy reliance on foreign private parties to supply not
 -7- only capital but also technology and management. There was scarcely any break with the colonial period. The strategy was essentially to carry on as before. Little attention was given to issues (b) and (c). The desira- bility of promoting industry outside Nairobi, Dar-es-Salaam and the copper- belt in Zambia was mentioned halfheartedly. Very little was said about the size structure of enterprises. 10. As far as issue (a) is concerned, the emphasis was clearly on import substitution. Competing in world markets was considered to be beyond the range of feasibility but there was considerable interest in regional markets. Kenya and Tanzania had free trade behind a common external tariff since 1927. These arrangements, initiated during the colonial period, had engendered much controversy. An official report written in 1932 recommended that t"Tanganyika should . . . cease to deplete her revenue and impoverish her citizens by protecting the products of her neighbors"l/ (i.e., Kenya). With independence, the new Tanzanian authorities could have withdrawn from the East African arrangements but decided not to do so. Instead, they negotiated substantial alterations in these regional arrangements with the hope that Tanzania would secure a fairer share of benefits than had accrued to her up to that time. All the details of these alterations reflected in the Raisman Report, the Kampala Agreement and the 1967 Treaty are not relevant for this paper but the following aspects are important for a discussion of industrial strategy: - A modest scheme for fiscal redistribution to compensate for inequali- ties in the benefits of the Common Market was put into effect in 1961/62 and lasted till 1969. 1/ Colonial Office, Report by S.A. Smith Cmd. 4182, London HMSO, p. 25.
 -8- - Tanzania threatened to withdraw from the Common Market unless measures were taken to correct the imbalance in industrial invest- ment. An ad hoc allocation of some industries was made in 1964; electric light bulbs to Kenya, radios, motor tires and tubes, aluminum foil, circles and plain sheets to Tanzania. It was pro- posed that studies should be made to (i) identify industries whose viability required markets larger than that of any one member; (ii) determine the appropriate location of these industries in East Africa. A number of studies were undertaken, but the ad hoc allocation was never ratified by all parties. - The East African Development Bank was established in 1969 to pro- mote industrial development with special emphasis on relatively backward partner states. Its investments were to go to Tanzania (39%), Uganda (39%) and Kenya (22%). - Tanzania was authorized in 1967 to levy transfer taxes of up to 50% of the common external tariff for a period of eight years on products where it had capacity of its own. 11. The similarity of industrial strategies in the three countries ended in 1967 with the Arusha Declaration. This was part of a major transformation in the overall Tanz nian strategy of socio-economic development. The capitalis- tic road based on foreign capital was abandoned in favor of socialism and self-reliance. In the industrial sphere, there was a significant shift in position on almost all the issues listed in paragraph 7. We have already noted the changed posture vis-a-vis the East African Common Market. Transfer taxes were levied on 50 items imported from Kenya. The Second Plan (1969-74)
 -9- opted for a 'basic goods' strategy and this was further elaborated in the next plan. By 1996, the share of intermediate and capital goods was to be raised to 60%. Emphasis was to be placed on meeting the essential needs of the Tanzanian people through d7mestic resources. Special attention was to be given to the processing of local raw materials, e.g. cotton, hides and skins, sisal and cashews for the home and foreign markets. 12. The Arusha wind blew in Mulungushi in 1968 where Dr. Kaunda an- nounced a series of nationalizations and other reforms to implement Zambia's humanist philosophy. Here too the capitalist solution was rejected and the goal of self-reliance proclaimed. The Second Zambian Plan (1972-76) visuali- zed a rate of growth of value-added in manufacturing of 15% p.a. Its main emphasis was on import substitution. Major expansion of meat processing, dairy products and textile capacity was visualized. In addition, there was the intention to produce sulphuric acid for the mining industry and fertili- ser for farming. The aim of promoting small enterprises in rural areas was given considerable prominence,and it was believed that the opening up of the Tanzam railroad would generate many opportunities of this kind. The Third Zambian Plan (1979-83) did not represent much change in strategy, although the overall target for expansion of the sector was reduced to 8% p.a. There was more emphasis placed on exploiting local materials for both import sub- stitution and exports. Also, the Third Plan was critical of excessive capital intensity and insisted on the need to fabricate animal-drawn implements, hand tools and simple machines for the farm sector. 13. While Tanzania and Zambia opted for the socialist path, Kenya con- tinued to rely on private initiative, including private foreign investment. The long-term goal was 'localization of capitalism'. The Second Plan talked
 -10- about "...an active and growing participation of Kenyan citizens in manage- ment and ownership of industry". At one level, localization was promoted through (i) the refusal to give citizenship to alien minorities; (ii) the requirement that non-citizens obtain work permits; and (iii) the imposition of restrictions on foreign business in such areas as domestic trade (Ghai 1973). Nevertheless, the open door policy for large foreign investors in manufacturing continued intact. 14. Kenya's Fourth Plan (1979-83), formulated against the background of the death of the East African Common Market in 1977, shifted the emphasis of industrial strategy from production for the home and regional markets to a search for international markets. To prepare for the new phase, measures to rationalize industry and increase competitiveness are visualized. There is also a stronger emphasis than before on the promotion of small enterprises and the informal sector. 15. We will show in the next section that these strategies have left their mark on industrialization in the three countries. Of course, the pace of growth and structural change was also influenced heavily by longer-term historical factors and macro-economic developments during the past decade. C. Growth in the Manufacturing Sector 16. The manufacturing sector expanded'more rapidly in Kenya than in the other two countries over the period as a whole.(Figure 1-4 and Table 2). Up to the early 1970s, Zambia was leading the field but suffered a major setback; subsequently, output has been falling since 1974. The share of manufacturing in GDP climbed up from 6.8% in 1965 to 11.9% in 1973 but then dropped to 10.4% by 1977 (Annex Table 1). In Tanzania too, manufacturing output rose very rapidly in the initial period but slowed down after 1972. Kenya manufacturing output fell in 1975 then recovered briskly.

 -16- 17. Kenya's lead in the manufacturing field was already firmly established during the colonial period and the last 10-15 years have added to it. Efforts made by the other two countries to catch up have not yet borne fruit. There are three main reasons for this outcome. First, GDP growth has been faster in Kenya, thereby expanding the home market for manufactures and facilitating raw material supplies from the farm sector. Secondly, we have already noted that the policy frame for the manufacturing sector has been much more stable than in neighboring countries. To some extent, therefore, faster growth has been obtained by postponing structural and institutional changes. Finally, Kenya has long been a familiar country to foreigners and Nairobi's infra- structure is far superior to that of the other two countries. Accordingly, Kenyan industrial growth was aided by. the flow of foreign direct investment to a much larger extent than in the other two cases. 18. Relative to growth of GDP, manufacturing has increased most rapidly in Zambia, taking account of the entire period under review. Table 2 shows that the Zambian elasticity coefficient was almost 1.8, i.e., manufacturing value-added rose by 1.8% for each 1.0% rise in GDP. During 1964-73, the corresponding coefficient was 2.4, reflecting the rapidity of import sub- stitution in manufacturing. D. Scale and Pattern of Import Substitution 19. Import substitution was a major impetus behind Zambian industriali- zation; exports were unimportant and domestic demand rose at a much slower pace than in the other two countries. This is one of the conclusions of a statistical disaggregation of the sources of industrial growth we have carried out (Table 3). The lack of recent censuses of industry or input- output tables restricts the period over which this exercise can be carried
 -17- out but we have reason to believe that many of the conclusions apply over the entire period we are studying (Annex Note A). Import substitution accounts for 55% of the overall rise in Zambia's manufacturing output during 1965-72. A sharp expansion in the textile, clothing and leather industry reduced the share of imports in total supply of these items from 77% to 46% during this period (see Annex Table 5). Corresponding ratios for rubber, chemicals and petroleum products also declined very sharply. The import substitution drive was part of Zambia's search for self-reliance. In addition, it was spurred on by the rupture of her relationship with Southern Rhodesia in the wake of the latter's Unilateral Declaration of Independence. S. Rhodesia had been the customary source of manufactured consumer and light intermediate goods, but this stopped when Zambia imposed economic sanctions and closed the border in 1965. 20. Import substitution was a considerably smaller source of industrial growth in Kenya, with domestic demand and exports playing a larger role than in Zambia (Table 3). The share of imports in total supply of finished tex- tiles, clothing, beverages, tobacco and non-metallic mineral products dropped in Kenya; but this was offset to some extent by a heavier reliance on imports of food products, semi-processed textiles, footwear and wood (Annex Table 3). 21. The most surprising finding was that import substitution played no role whatever in overall expansion in Tanzanian manufacturing. This was so despite the emphasis on self-reliance in several strategy pronouncements. There was considerable import replacement of beverages, textiles, wearing apparel and non-metallic mineral products; but this was offset by increased reliance on imports of food products, wood products, furniture and fixtures, capital goods, metals and metal products (Annex Table 4). While the import coefficient fell sharply in Zambia and marginally in Tanzania, there was a large upsurge in the dependence of imports of Kenyan manufacturing. The coefficient of imported inputs rose by a full ten per- centage points and its absolute level at 30% in 1970 exceeded by far the corresponding proportion in neighboring countries. Import dependence was high in Kenya partly because the output-mix of the manufacturing sector there was much more diversified than in Tanzania and Zambia. The share of capital and intermediate goods in total Kenyan manufacturing output was higher, and these branches tend to have a larger import coefficient. If the Tanzanian manufacturing sector had Kenya's output- mix, then its overall import coefficient would be 18% in 1970 instead of the actual 14%. Another factor which may be responsible for Kenya's high import dependence is the fact that a large part of its industry is controlled by transnational corporations. These firms frequently preferred foreign inputs to local ones on the grounds that the former were more compatible with the technological process in use and their supply was more dependable. E. Behavior of Manufactured Exports 26. Exports were a significant part of manufacturing production in Kenya and Tanzania, and the regional East African Common Market (EACM) accounted
 -21- for a substantial part of overseas sales (Table 4). Unfortunately, the Comidon Market failed to expand rapidly and collapsed in 1977. Exports to inter- national markets increased more rapidly--especially in the case of Kenya. But, altogether, the export orientation of the manufacturing sector in these two countries diminished. Zambia's manufacturing continued to ignore export sales. 27. A number of Kenyan industrial branches were exporting more than half their output in the early 1960s; this was the case in meat and dairy products, canned fruits and vegetables, fabrics, footwear, wood, leather, petroleum, chemicals, and cement (Annex Table 9). More than 50% of overseas sales of processed tobacco, petroleum, chemicals, basic manufactures, batteries and insulated wire were destined for the EACM (Annex Table 10). Transfer taxes had been imposed on many of these items in 1967 by Kenya's trading partners and behind these protective barriers, Tanzanian and Ugandan firms were growing up and gaining experience. By 1976, Kenya had lost her East African market for processed food, beverages and tobacco and many types of miscellaneous manufactures. Sales of basic manufactures had risen slowly. By contrast, Kenyan exports of petroleum and chemicals expanded rapidly and insulation wire and batteries became a prominent new line of business. Al- together total sales to EACM doubled during 1965-76; an annual growth rate of 2.3% (Table 4). 28. Kenya succeeded in entering many new markets in U.K., Western Europe and in African countries such as Zambia, Sudan, Rwanda and Mauritius. Her manufactured exports to non-EACM markets rose from $35 million to $219 million during 1965-76; an annual growth rate of 16% (Table 4). These adverse trends were caused by: (i) unfavourable international economic conditions, including a sizeable deterioration in terms of trade; (ii) internal shocks such as droughts and widespread political and civil conflict and, (iii) policy failures, e.g. massive increase in the responsibilities of the public sector in the face of acute scarcity of skilled managers, administrators and technicians leading to gross inefficiency.

doc.abstracts: Based on the existing literature and the circumscribed data base, this paper assesses the extent and nature of industrialization in three African countries. After a promising start, the drive to industrialize is now faltering. The record is influenced much more by the colonial legacy and the macro-economic situation of each country than by industrial policy. It is clear that future industrial advance will depend heavily on the pace of rural development. Catering to world markets is not likely to provide a major stimulus for the industrial sector of many African economies in the near term future.
